thebootfitter

Several times in these forums I have stated that there is no way to KNOW in the realm in which we exist whether or not there is a God or gods. Within this realm, we can only believe. Ultimately, there is no logic in a belief in God... it is belief. It is faith, and as such, needs no logic to back it up.
 
 What I am asking now is this: 
 Is it possible to transcend this realm in which our physical bodies exist and KNOW that which is unknowable through observation, logic, and reason in this realm? Is it possible to KNOW anything that is knowable in all realms of existence -- physical or otherwise -- via trascendence of this realm? Is it possible that there is a state of being that makes the pursuit of truth through observation,logic and reason as elementary and laughable as faith and belief appear to be from the perspective of logic and reason?
whistler

What I am asking now is this: 
 Is it possible to transcend this realm in which our physical bodies exist and KNOW that which is unknowable through observation, logic, and reason in this realm? Is it possible to KNOW anything that is knowable in all realms of existence -- physical or otherwise -- via trascendence of this realm? Is it possible that there is a state of being that makes the pursuit of truth through observation,logic and reason as elementary and laughable as faith and belief appear to be from the perspective of logic and reason?

 
 How would you know that you were able to sucessfully transcend this realm? Wouldn't this knowedge require some sort of faith?
 
 Whistler
Big Orn

It has been done: Abraham, Moses, Elijah, Enoch, and Apostle Paul to name a few.
 But, I have come to realize that unless you have a documented process that can be duplicated by several reputable sources at any given time, over and over again, then that process or event will always be unbelievable.
thebootfitter

How would you know that you were able to sucessfully transcend this realm?

 You would know it when you know it. When you experienced it. Not when you thought you experienced it or believed you experienced it.
 
 
Wouldn't this knowedge require some sort of faith? 

 Faith in what? Faith that the knowledge is 'truth'? No. Because with knowledge, there is no need for faith. An analogy can be drawn from a typical discussion with a 'creationist':
 Creationist: You 'believe' in science, just like I believe in God.
 Other: No. The universe doesn't require belief in order to operate as it operates. Science is the observation and understanding of how the universe operates.
thebootfitter

It has been done: Abraham, Moses, Elijah, Enoch, and Apostle Paul to name a few.
 But, I have come to realize that unless you have a documented process that can be duplicated by several reputable sources at any given time, over and over again, then that process or event will always be unbelievable.

 What about Mohammed? And Buddha? Perhaps Ghandi?
 
 Do you really think it matters to one who has transcended the physical world whether or not anyone 'believes' them?
whistler

What I am asking now is this: 
 Is it possible to transcend this realm in which our physical bodies exist and KNOW that which is unknowable through observation, logic, and reason in this realm? Is it possible to KNOW anything that is knowable in all realms of existence -- physical or otherwise -- via trascendence of this realm? Is it possible that there is a state of being that makes the pursuit of truth through observation,logic and reason as elementary and laughable as faith and belief appear to be from the perspective of logic and reason?

 
 How in the world would I know?!
 
 Pardon me for ignoring your response for a minute while we got back to the basics.
 
 
Faith in what? Faith that the knowledge is 'truth'? No. Because with knowledge, there is no need for faith. 

 If you think you can do it, fine. You can do it, just don't expect other people to believe you. If you 'know' that you possess all the knowledge you gleaned from some other existential plane...good for you. Wait...I see your response to Big Orn
 
Do you really think it matters to one who has transcended the physical world whether or not anyone 'believes' them?

 So if you are going to be going on this spiritual journey that will ostensibly open the secrets of the universe to you, and you don't care whether we will believe you when you get back, why are you asking this question?
 
 Is this another fishing expedition?
 
 Whistler
unkerpaulie

wow, whistler. you could have just as well not responded altogether...
 
 bootfitter, if it were possible to trandscend into the spirit realm and obtain evidence of God's existence, then the process should be replicable and teachable. anyone of sufficient knowledge and discipline should be able to transcend regularly once they have practiced enough
 
 the thing is, for centuries men have been talking about entering the spiritual realm, through meditation, etc. also, there are countless reports of people who have had near-death experiences and regained conciousness bringing back vivid descriptions of paradise/hell while in their unconcious state. and these experiences are nothing like dreams people would normally have.
 
 i think at the end of it all its a matter of faith. all these phenomenon can be explained by "science" as purely mental, and that no spiritual realm has been visited. off course, the observer himself may be very convinced that he has reached a spiritual realm. however, all he/she would have is a strong conviction and nothing else. what if the experience was simply due to the brain's reaction to extreme trauma?
 
 i think if it were possible and duplicable, then we wouldnt be sitting here discussing if it were possible or not
Big Orn

What about Mohammed? And Buddha? Perhaps Ghandi?
 
 Do you really think it matters to one who has transcended the physical world whether or not anyone 'believes' them?

 They could have...
 
 Do you believe that you once were in the presence of God? Do you believe that we were once in a battle that involved good against evil - before the earth was restored to its present state? I do.
 
 It matters in order for someone besides yourself to have an idea why in the world anyone in their right mind would even think of such a thing. It matters in order for someone to understand why the Holy Bible still has the impact and effect is has for so many years.
 
 I can still be in the presence of God and am everyday, believe it or not.
 
 The Bible is not a work of fiction.
epaphras_faith

Several times in these forums I have stated that there is no way to KNOW in the realm in which we exist whether or not there is a God or gods. Within this realm, we can only believe. Ultimately, there is no logic in a belief in God... it is belief. It is faith, and as such, needs no logic to back it up.
 
 What I am asking now is this: 
 Is it possible to transcend this realm in which our physical bodies exist and KNOW that which is unknowable through observation, logic, and reason in this realm? Is it possible to KNOW anything that is knowable in all realms of existence -- physical or otherwise -- via trascendence of this realm? Is it possible that there is a state of being that makes the pursuit of truth through observation,logic and reason as elementary and laughable as faith and belief appear to be from the perspective of logic and reason?

 
 Unfortunately, I do not accept your premise and therefore my statements are skewed accordingly. If my non acceptance of the premise denies my qualification to post in this thread then say so and I will post no further on this subject. 
 
 The problem with your logic is that you assume that belief in No God does not require faith and is therefore logical, not illogical. To say there is no God (which you cannot prove) and to say there is a God (which I cannot prove) both require faith or belief. That faith or belief can be based on a logical thought process none the less. We may differ in our conclusions and still both have correctly used logic. The use of logic does not guaranty the CORRECT answer. One must also have the correct assumptions to arrive at the correct answer. The problem with your logic is that you assume facts not in evidence. Namely, you assume that there is no God. You look at the fossil record or whatever and then with minimal knowledge and understanding (because you are not omniscient) you declare there is no God. This is belief. Not proof.
 
 Therefore, the concept of transendance is irrelevant to me. You have not presented a logical argument to assume you base assumptions and therefore I am unable to go further.
thebootfitter

Unfortunately, I do not accept your premise and therefore my statements are skewed accordingly. 

 Which part of the premise do you not accept? The premise is simply this: the number of gods is unknowable in the physical realm in which we exist. We do not and cannot know, in this realm, whether there is one God, many gods, or no gods. If we believe in a God or gods or in no god, then we do so by faith. Because knowledge of this does not exist in our realm.
 
 
The problem with your logic is that you assume that belief in No God does not require faith and is therefore logical, not illogical.

 Where have I said this? Read again.
 
 
Therefore, the concept of transendance is irrelevant to me. You have not presented a logical argument to assume you base assumptions and therefore I am unable to go further. 

 If you don't accept my premise, then please tell me how we can KNOW the number of gods that exist. We cannot. You said so yourself: "...and to say there is a God (which I cannot prove)..." Nowhere here do I assert that there is no God. You made that up.
 
 If you wish to continue the discussion (which I welcome you to do), please re-read the question and do not jump to conclusions.
 
 Peace,
 The Bootfitter
 P.S. I'll be out paddling all weekend. Have a good one!
